responses.rationale: Reports facts about illness severity and outcomes without explicit calming language.
Reports a wide spectrum of severity in human infections without explicit calming language.
Reports some cases were mild but also notes the possibility of serious illness, lacking explicit calming cues.
Reports a negative outcome in ferret experiments without explicit calming language.
Reports lack of existing immunity without explicit calming language.
Reports lack of existing immunity without explicit calming language.
Reports the virus would look different to human bodies without explicit calming language.
Reports viruses can change and spread quickly without explicit calming language.
Reports viruses can change quickly without explicit calming language.
Reports potential for the virus to change and spread without explicit calming language.
Reports potential for sudden change without explicit calming language.
Reports a planned action (repeat tests) without explicit calming language.
The phrase 'These early ferret experiments are good news' is explicit positive amplification.
Reports low human infections but notes limited testing; lacks explicit calming language or intensified low-risk evaluation.
Reports the virus is not well adapted to respiratory spread (a positive fact) but lacks explicit calming language.
Describes an experimental method without explicit calming language.
Reports experimental outcome (ferrets became ill) without explicit calming language.
Describes an experimental setup without explicit calming language.
Describes an experimental setup without explicit calming language.
Reports a positive finding (unlikely airborne transmission) but lacks explicit calming language.
Reports positive outcomes (no severe symptoms, no transmission) but lacks explicit calming language.
Reports successful treatment (a positive fact) but lacks explicit calming language.
Reports symptoms developed without explicit calming language.
Reports an exposure event without explicit calming language.
Reports infections developed without explicit calming language.
Reports 'dead-end infections,' which is a technical term, not explicit calming language about public safety.
Reports the virus is not well-adapted to humans (a positive fact) but lacks explicit calming language.
Explains how a type of infection happens without explicit calming language.
Defines a technical term ('dead-end infections') without explicit calming language.
Reports low transmission rate (a positive fact) but lacks explicit calming language.
Reports high fatality rate but also low infectivity; lacks explicit calming language.
Reports infections have been sporadic and self-limiting (positive facts) but lacks explicit calming language.
Expresses sadness about disease progression, which is not a calming cue.
Reports severity of symptoms, which is not a calming cue.
Reports negative outcome (succumb) in foxes without explicit calming language.
Reports lack of prior knowledge without explicit calming language.
Reports worsening symptoms without explicit calming language.
Reports severe symptoms without explicit calming language.
Reports negative symptoms without explicit calming language.
Reports prior experience and surprise at severity, not a calming cue.
Reports potential negative future outcome without explicit calming language.
Explains mutation process and that errors often don't favor the virus (a positive fact) but lacks explicit calming language.

Explains mutation process and that errors often don't favor the virus (a positive fact) but lacks explicit calming language.
Reports humans aren't intended targets (a positive fact) but immediately follows with potential negative change; lacks explicit calming language.
Uses loaded metaphor 'collateral damage,' which is not a calming cue.
Uses vivid language ('voraciousness') and reports a negative label ('pandemic'), not a calming cue.
Uses metaphor ('Swiss Army Knife') and reports negative outcomes (infected/killed millions), not a calming cue.
Reports a challenge ('to contend with'), not a calming cue.
Describes difficult work conditions without explicit calming language.
Reports a confirmed case (a bare fact) without explicit calming language.
The phrase 'working to confirm the safety of milk and meat products' is a direct safety assurance.
The phrase 'reaffirm that the meat supply is safe' is a direct consumption safety assurance.
Reports negative test results (a positive fact) but lacks explicit calming language.
Reports negative outcomes ('worst season,' 'culled,' 'affected') without explicit calming language.
Reports outbreaks and large numbers of affected poultry without explicit calming language.
Reports increase in cases, deaths, and critical illness without explicit calming language.
Reports 'source of concern,' which is not a calming cue.
The phrase 'we do not believe that there is any possibility... transmitted to humans through the consumption' is a strong confidence statement about consumption safety.
Reports culling and control measures (bare facts) without explicit calming language.
Reports an outbreak and uses a technical term ('highly pathogenic') without explicit calming language.
Reports positive findings (no changes increasing likelihood or hindering antivirals) but lacks explicit calming language.
Reports spread of the outbreak without explicit calming language.
Reports absence of human-to-human transmission (a positive fact) but lacks explicit calming language.
Provides safety advice (prevention measures), not an explicit calming cue about current safety.
Mentions 'risks currently being low' but this is not intensified ('very low') and is part of advice to take measures.
Reports recommendation for future prevention, not a calming cue about current safety.
Reports high fatality rate without explicit calming language.
Reports symptoms without explicit calming language.

Reports health alert recommendations, not a calming cue about public safety.
